On Apr 13, 2007, at 2:12 PM, Darren Izzard wrote:

> So you're correct that propagation through the network is not complete
> at each timestep. But I don't see why you claim NEAT cannot converge
> under these circumstances.

I didn't claim that NEAT cannot converge under those circumstances.

I said that *if* your solution *required* recurrent connections,  
*and* you were indeed fully evaluating the networks (as in a sorted  
node, single update), that NEAT would not converge.

On the other hand, if you are not updating the network completely, as  
it seems to be the case here, then sure, you could get networks that  
are responding in a delayed fashion (as indeed it may work in biology).

Furthermore, if your network update iteration count is fixed, then,  
as networks are smaller, it's easy to see how the excitation at the  
inputs would make it through the network; however, as networks  
increase in size, they can easily outgrow the fixed iteration count,  
such that inputs may not make it all the way through the network.   
This, in turn, creates a time delay or memory.

I've never worked with non-recurrent neural networks where inputs  
were not properly propagated all the way through the network; hence,  
my confusion.

--Steve
